title: Can a sociopath also be autistic? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don't know, to be honest. But I don't that that's a likely thing and I'll go on and explain why. What looks like sociopathy could just be part of your autism, especially if, like me, you have a bit of the ' Sherlock Holmes' personality or you Seem ( key word=seem) not to care about other stuff as much as others do and that makes some people perceive us as sociopaths. But to be a sociopath you must have certain traits consistently and it really requires a diagnosis from a professional. I think when ignorant people label autistic people sociopaths they're kind of downplaying how their disability might affect them and it's making a lot of biased assumptions. Plus if you consider that as autistic people we are usually developmentally younger in some ways than our chronological age, it makes sense that we could appear a bit sociopathic, as a lot of behaviour children do you wouldn't think appropriate of an adult. I'm not saying autistic people are completely like children, not necessarily and in my case definitely not in understanding and maturity but, especially if one is in a burnout phase, their symptoms might manifest more severely. Basically it's really not fair to label someone sociopathic if they have a severe disability, IMO. Not even to label yourself that. You can see a therapist if you're concerned that you might be a sociopath as well but in my view, autistic people on the whole are very different from sociopaths in a lot of ways. For one thing, sociopaths enjoy manipulating others for their own gain and don't care about the effects of their actions on others. From my experience and what I've seen of a lot of autistic people, many of us do usually care about what others think of us (even if it may not appear that way to someone who doesn't understand autism) and we don't go out of our way to deliberately manipulate or hurt people because we don't want to, wheras sociopaths often do. Autistic people often like keeping to ourselves and we can be naiive at times or too honest. Sociopaths tend to be more subtle with their words to manipulate people and take advantage of people who speak more openly. In my experience, a lot of ' normal' people act like sociopaths but don't see it that way and then accuse anyone they don't understand or don't like of being a sociopath. And anyway any behaviour that is antisocial, if that's what you're thinking about, is a behaviour not a diagnosis. And I think this is one of the reasons that sociopathy is perceived by some as a wishy washy label because it might encompass a set of traits that could occur in various different people but which could have very different causes in different individuals. However, I guess if an autistic person has been raised in the kind of environment that could foster sociopathy, then a dual diagnosis might be more likely. But then it might still be unclear what's more down to their autism or due to their environment. I guess it's still really a matter of how these two interact with one another. In my experience moral scrupulosity makes it extremely difficult for me to ever intentionally cause people harm. If you don't have moral scrupulosity it's possible that you could be more sociopathic in some of your behaviour. Basically if you're still unsure, I think that you should seek support from a therapist but I don't really see the point in getting more labels unless you think that would really help you. It's actually a stigma, wheras getting therapy for whatever problems you're having is still a good idea and may help you more than any label could. Especially if you feel that any of your behaviour is very disruptive to yourself and others. Also I think that you have to be an adult- ideally your brain being fully developed and everything- to be given a ‘diagnosis’ of sociopathy. And I'm guessing you'd benefit more from help than a label that might serve nothing better than making people afraid of you if they aren't already. But maybe you wouldn't have to reveal it to anyone, I'm not sure. My knowledge of this ends here I'm afraid.

Yes. He/she can be a logical reasonable sociopath.  What you mean by being a sociopath is probably someone who ignores general rules that most people accept (morality, rules of interaction, values,...). In that sense, an autistic person that is not well accompanied and socialized can develop interests that can lead them to become hostile to people, whom they can view as a nuisance. To an autistic person, people can easily look as irrational stupid destroyers who respect nothing and have no no understanding of logic. People usually don't see the beauty of the world as autistic people do. They see plain reality where autistic people can see patterns, or simply a fascinating subject. Basically, all that comes back to the fact that an autistic person can easily become a sociopath by :- hating people for being the irrational illogical unpredictable beings they tend to be. (usually because they get hurt by others, sometimes even their simple presence)- not having any empathy for others, thus considering humans as having the same value as a rock. In that case, humans can be hurt or destroyed without any moral problem. (by the way, it's something you can teach, by bringing autistic people in the circle of the human condition. It's easy to see oneself as not human when you are so radically different from EVERYONE else)- developping specific interests and values that do not include humans as important. (for instance, a passion for nuclear bombs can lead an autistic person to work in situations where they don't care about morality. I think that can be qualified as sociopathy. Same thing applies in other fields simply because autistic people tend to develop their own values if the ones around them seem illogical. Most people do not realize how deeply the values a society holds are emotional and built on emotional and illogical constructions.)

Maybe an autistic person could be a sociopath, but would they even be a threat if they were? Feel free to correct me if I’m wrong, but isn’t the main threat or strength of a sociopath or psychopath that they are supposedly good at manipulating others? Autistic people don’t have a good grasp of social situations, and we’re limited on how much we can actually “learn” when it comes to social situations. It doesn’t make us deceptive but extremely awkward. People often assume there’s something “wrong” and accuse us of being “rude” and maybe even “mean” when we aren’t trying to be that way at all. I would think that if I were to actually try to deceive or hurt other people, I would not only be doing myself a disservice but I also might be doing a disservice to those people who also want to leave good impressions on other people. A sociopath or psychopath, on the other hand, they’re master manipulators. They can do the worst things to you and then charm you back with their charisma and fake warm personalities. When I think of someone like that, I think of the man who beats his wife and then goes to work, maybe as a singer or some kind of career artist, without acting like he’s done anything wrong at all. I might also think of the woman who verbally berates, physically bullies, and emotionally manipulates her husband. I wouldn’t peg someone like that as autistic, because they have too much skill in the social areas. This is one thing I think the uniformed get wrong about those of us on the autism spectrum too much of the time; we are literally not able to understand certain social cues or respond appropriatly in some social situations. We can’t turn it on and off. If we’re accidentally rude to the waitress, we’ll probably accidentally be rude to the person we love. It’s not something we do out of spite or out of not caring; it’s simply because we do not know. An autistic person who stopped caring about social situations period or whether or not they hurt other people would probably be the first to get caught, the first to go to jail, pretty much the first to get punished, period, because we already give people all of the wrong non-verbal signals. It’s a fairly strong incentive to stay on the right side of the law and not hurt other people, and I could see even a person with no actual feelings for other people respecting their own freedom and desire not to be punished enough to try to stay on others’ good side. Maybe I’m biased, but to my knowledge I’ve never met anyone who had problems relating to other people who fell into the category of con-artist or violent manipulative sociopath; they simply lack the skills and knowledge to do things like that. It’s more likely that they would just start avoiding people, or if they decided to try being around people, approach it gradually and learn from their mistakes. There’s no room for deception, regardless of how cruel people can be. To an autistic person, trying to learn how to manipulate someone might be kind of like a kid who doesn’t know how to add or subtract attempting Algebra. You’d be able to spot our mistakes and read our bad intentions right away.

That’s an interesting question. Actually, the two are the antithesis of one another and recent research would air me out, here. You see, the most recent findings of autism reveal that they’re not devoid of feeling, but rather they have so much empathy it can drive them crazy and cause them to ignore the world around them otherwise they’d go nuts with all the guilt. As an autistic person myself (hello!), I can tell you that this is true. It’s incredibly easy for me to place blame upon myself and end up feeling guilty over the most ridiculous things. This is a common autistic problem, because the neurotypical mind doesn’t really have empathy dialled up so radically. There’s a nasty realisation to be had, here, of course. Yes. Unscrupulous NTs and sociopaths alike will abuse autistic people, they’ll use that empathy to exploit them. This is why we become very aware of manipulative people early on, and we’re likely to just shut them out. Neurotypicals use manipulations as part of the unspoken social contracts that make up their intuited interactions with others like them. To an NT, manipulation is simply an aspect of social bargaining. Autistic people are bad at manipulation and have an innate disliking of it. We’re terrible liars, too, because it draws from the same set of tools. It’s why autistic people are so honest and our lack of ‘fakeness’ can be quite disconcerting to NTs, it can catch them off guard. We’re very open and blunt because we don’t really know any other way to be, we’re not unkind though so often we’ll guard our words very carefully so that we won’t hurt anyone. Sociopaths, on the other hand, excel at manipulation. It’s what they do best. Their mind is designed to excel at the social games that NTs play, that autistic people try not to. Furthermore, a sociopath, unlike an autistic person, feels little to no empathy or guilt. The closest you can get is that they’ll feel sorry for themselves if they get caught. You’ll find communities of sociopaths online who’ll talk about how much they enjoy manipulating empaths because they love seeing what they can get away with. A sociopath is in their oils when they’re manipulating and exploiting people, most of all. Of course, when a sociopath doesn’t get their way, they’re likely to become aggressive, dialling the manipulation up to 11, and really bringing the predator out for all to see. If people start calling them on it, they’re liable to go a bit crazy. They’ll make a big, public display and try and manipulate everyone present, they’ll be trying to play everyone against one another. If an autistic person is confronted, their first instinct is to escape because they can sense the manipulations present and they want no part of it. NTs and sociopaths alike revel in manipulations. Autistic people? Not so much. It’s why I’ve often theorised that there are two spectrums at play here with levels of severity. Autistic spectrum: Extreme <-[Autism]-[Asperger’s]-[Introversion]-> Shallow NT spectrum: Extreme <-[Sociopathy]-[Agentic Extraversion]-[Affiliative Extraversion]-> Shallow This idea has been picking up steam as parts of it are slowly entering into the public consciousness. First of all, the hypothesis that introversion is the ‘nonclinical’ end of the autistic spectrum [you can read about that here]; The hypothesis that extraversion is split up between agentic and affiliative [you can read about that here]; This study showing that extraverts are much more likely to be unfaithful in relationships, more narcissistic, and display psychopathic traits [you can read about that here]; And this study showing that Internet trolls are extraverts with psychopathic traits [you can read about that here]. I hope these are enough citations to support my hypothesis. As I said, I think it’s a growing realisation. And an interesting one, to be sure. So, yes, autism and sociopathy are opposites, but it goes deeper even than that.

There's been nothing indicating sociopathy/psychopathy is more or less common among autistic people. There's been no known case of an autistic person suffering from psychopathy. So the ultimate answer is: We don't know. However, if we were to assume that they are neither more common or more rare together than separate, as about 1/70 are autistic and 1/150 are psychopaths, we'd see about 1 person in 10500 be both psychopathic and autistic. Some of the traits of autism may be similar to some of the traits of psychopathy, but most traits are completely different. As Nell Rus says, we can have a hard time with social subtext and body language, while psychopaths are generally excellent at those things. We may have a hard time empathizing, but mostly because we have a hard time figuring out how others feel, unlike with psychopathy where it seems they can understand what others feel but are still not empathic. I will object to Nell Rus' description on that autistic people won't go out of their way to harm others. We are people, and like most other people we are different from each others and we're also not constant; just like allistics we change over our lives. Autistics are not more prone to go out of our way to harm others, but like, it's just not a trait related to autism either way. There are mean people with autism, there are peaceful people with autism. And even if one isn't a mean person, sometimes anyone can get vengeful or vindictive under the right (wrong) circumstances. I have yet to meet an autistic that doesn't like cats, though.  But, again, we have nothing indicating anything about this. It's a rather strange question, honestly.

Autistic sociopaths exists. My father was one, fit all the patterns of both. Not sure of you know this film:  The MC of this film goes from a mental illness sufferer to a dangerously borderline megalomaniac, just by receiving an experimental treatment to enhance his mental strength. Conversely, my father was highly inteligent, prone to temper tantrums and with a heightened view of self. But he had no feelings or love lost for anyone, he had urges to be satisfied and boredom to be quenched. He cared not of what or who he would destroy to get what he craved. He loved seeing people humiliated or hurt. His only distraction in life was making his family and friends the targets of his constant frustration with life. His poor social skills made him as charming as feared, so he used those “eccentricities” to cause as much harm as possible and never suffer any backlash. “Oh, that is how he is, pay no mind!” As an autistic person, he saw no wrong in what he was doing. As a sociopathic individual, he saw only what was in it for him. So yes, such a combination exists. And I pray you never encounter someone like this.

Autism spectrum disorders are characterized by difficulties communicating and processing emotions. Because of this, in particular cases, especially with high functioning autism, (to somebody that doesn’t understand them) the symptoms can mimic symptoms expressed by sociopaths. When it comes to physiologically induced mental disorders, you either have them or you don’t, they're not aquired. It may be possible for a person with ASD to also be born a sociopath, but any person you may believe is a sociopath that has autism is most likely a construct of misunderstanding. An example of this is myself. Many times I'm emotionally expressionless and am very blunt with people. I acknowledge only facts and don’t let emotions could my judgment and form a bias. However, at other times, I'm very creative and genuinely emotionally receptive, possess empathy, and experience the same emotional patterns as normally functioning humans. Right now I'm speaking in a calculated manner with little emotion, but at a future point in time I will be very friendly, funny, and more casual. Adequately responding in accordance with social constructs seems to be a great difficulty in people with autism spectrum disorders and thusly symptoms can occur at what can be “improper” times.

You can’t just “become” a sociopath. That’s not how it works. Sociopathy stems from trauma at a young age. Some undiagnosed people with high-functioning autism have mistakenly thought they have sociopathy, when they simply struggle with empathy. Additionally, there are neurotypicals that struggle with empathy but are not sociopaths.

No. An autistic person has problems emapthizing with others but they won't go out of their way to harm others. On the contrary, many are quite compassionate and love animals like cats, dogs, etc. Autistics have a weak theory of mind so they struggle immensely at figuring out the reasons behind other people's behavior and reading body language. By contrast, the sociopath is great at reading others and figuring out intentions but they will use them to achieve their own ends and manipulate others without any qualms at all.

Well, because autism doesn't look any one which way for every person, it would be possible if there was an agreed upon medical definition for sociopathy but there is not. However, when people say “sociopath” they are often (unknowingly sometimes) talking about someone with Antisocial Personality Disorder. I do know autistic people that are also diagnosed ASPD as well. So, I suppose there is your answer. Yes

If we take the view of sociopathy “often arising from environmental factors” (Psychology Today) — then yes, on account of a society that is extremely prejudiced in rendering itself hostile towards those on the spectrum from cradle to grave! Sad to note, that it will be easy for people to label those on the spectrum as anti-social, even if they are clinically not deemed to be, just because they are often different from the popular voice of the room. Had they been anti-social, they would leave the room, find a bigger following in another room, then exercise revenge on the first! If I can speak for others, we are contempt with staying anyways or finding a healthier room — we only take on the first if the topic of our difference is consequentially significant in its error of judgement. So, I think it is not mutually exclusive, but it is not quite as straightforward due to the atypical complexities it involves when trying to explain from one’s behaviour. Does that look like the kind of answer you were going for?

There are many similarities between the two (assuming, incorrectly for the purposes of your question, that “sociopathy” is an agreed upon term), depending on where you would fall on the autism spectrum. The inability to understand the emotional state of another and possible inability to empathize with them is, perhaps, a cross-over symptom. If you are worried about either I would suggest you see a professional.

It has not been “officially” proven, however I hypothesize differently. Childhood trauma is what creates a Sociopath. People with ASD (particularly HF) are highly vulnerable to abuse (from both family and peers) during childhood years. My hypothesis is that the Aspie may learn about the dark side of human nature and rebel towards humanity due to their consistent learning that everyone they met is an asshole. Here’s a question, if you were the 1% of people (ASD people make up 1%) and had been bullied from various people your entire life would you not learn that you need to look out for yourself while not caring about anyone else?

Sadly, there is a great deal of overlap between the NT definition of Sociopathy and HFA/Aspergers. I spent almost a decade believing I was a “Functional Sociopath” before I was diagnosed as ASD-PDD/NOS (Aspergers). This is entirely an NT problem, labling people they don't understand with labels they don't understand because they have no diagnostic training. And it is crippling to people with Autism.

Frankly, autism has become almost meaningless as a diagnosis due to becoming overly generalized and a sociological phenomenon of many individuals self-diagnosing. It can become a potent and dangerous mix when combined with ideological movements online that enforce a person’s right to do so. This scenario could certainly invite a sociopath looking for a means of manipulation, latching onto groups with many potential and easy prey.

You can’t become one in the sense I think you mean. I’m both autistic (Aspergers) and a Sociopath. I suppose in a sense I was born one (autistic) and events of my childhood made me the other. So, I suppose the real answer to your question would be kind of.
